column1: Rockhampton is a city in the Rockhampton Region of Central Queensland
column2: Australia. The population of Rockhampton in June 2018 was 78
column4: making it the fourth-largest city in the state outside of the cities of South East Queensland
column5: and the 22nd-largest city in Australia.

column1: Rockhampton is one of the oldest cities in Queensland and in Northern Australia. In 1853
column2: Charles and William Archer came across what is now also known as the Fitzroy River
column3: which they named in honour of Sir Charles FitzRoy. The Archer brothers took up a run near Gracemere in 1855
column4: and more settlers arrived soon after
column5: enticed by the fertile valleys. The town of Rockhampton was proclaimed in 1858
column6: and surveyed by William Henry Standish (Supervisor of Main Roads Department and later Foreman of Works)
column7: Arthur F Wood and Francis Clarke
column8: the chosen street design closely resembled the Hoddle Grid in Melbourne and consisted of a grid of wide boulevards and laneways

column1: Within the year
column2: gold was found at Canoona
column3: and led to the first North Australian gold rush. This led to an influx of migrants who quickly transformed Rockhampton into the second-largest port in the state; during this period
column4: Rockhampton was nicknamed as the "City of the Three S's"
column5: of which were "Sin
column6: Sweat
column7: and Sorrow". Subsequent gold rushes at Mount Morgan Mine
column8: which was at the time one of the most productive gold mines in the world
column9: laid the foundations for much of the city's Victorian architecture.

column1: Today
column2: Rockhampton is an industrial and agricultural centre of the north
column3: and is the regional centre of Central Queensland. Rockhampton is also a large tourist destination known for its history and culture supporting such institutions as the Rockhampton Art Gallery
column4: one of the most extensive regional galleries in Australia
column5: the Central Queensland University with campuses across five states
column6: the Rockhampton Heritage Village
column7: and Dreamtime Cultural Centre. It is also famous as the hometown of Rod Laver – one of the best tennis players in history.The city is served by the Rockhampton Airport and acts as a gateway to local tourist locations such as the Capricorn Caves and Mount Archer National Park
column8: as well as regional tourist areas such as Yeppoon and the Capricorn Coast alongside the island chains offshore that include Great Keppel Island.

column1: == History ==
=== Indigenous Australians ===
The Capricorn district is the traditional home of the Darumbal Aboriginal people. The Darumbal (Tarumbul
column2: Tharoombool) language region includes the city of Rockhampton extending south towards Raglan Creek and north towards the Styx River and inland along the Broad Sound Ranges. The Gangulu (Kangulu
column3: Kanolu
column4: Kaangooloo
column5: Khangulu) language region includes the towns of Clermont and Springsure extending south towards the Dawson River
column6: and includes parts of Rockhampton and South Rockhampton.

column1: === Early British settlement ===
The British settlement of the area began in 1853
column2: when the Archer brothers
column3: Charles and William
column4: who were seeking grazing lands arrived in the Rockhampton area. They were acting on information from earlier expeditions by Ludwig Leichhardt and Thomas Mitchell
column5: who had explored the area in 1844 and 1846 and noted suitable land for grazing then.In January 1854
column6: the New South Wales government proclaimed two new districts: Port Curtis and Leichhardt (roughly today's Fitzroy Region)
column7: and the Archer brothers returned in August 1855 to set up their pastoral run at Gracemere. The Fitzroy River provided a convenient waterway for shipping of supplies and produce
column8: and the Archer brothers constructed a wool shed just downstream of a bar of rocks that prevented further upstream navigation from the coast. These rocks were incorporated with the traditional English term for a village
column9: and the name "Rockhampton" was first coined by Charles Archer and the local Commissioner from Crown Lands
column11: the Elliott brothers arrived at Gracemere and soon after
column14: Philip Elliott and his party came under attack from the Darumbals
column15: possibly of the Taroomball tribe. Elliott was seriously wounded by a spear and one of his men was killed. However
column16: Elliott had brought with his party a contingent of Native Police
column17: who turned near-certain loss into victory. It was the first of many battles.Permanent British settlement at the Rockhampton township began in July 1856
column18: when Richard Palmer travelled from Gladstone with an escort of Native Police under sub-Lieutenant Walter Powell to set up a store. Powell arrived at the site first and constructed the Native Police barracks. This was the first habitable British building established at Rockhampton and it was located on the south bank of the Fitzroy River at the end of Albert Street.

column1: With abundant grazing lands and waters from the Fitzroy River and its many tributaries and lagoons
column2: the region continued to expand rapidly. In 1858
column3: the town of Rockhampton was officially proclaimed. The town was surveyed at this time and the first sales of building allotments were held that year. In 1859
column4: gold was discovered at Canoona. Miners rushed to the new field
column5: using the site of Rockhampton on the Fitzroy River as the nearest navigable port. The Canoona field proved to be very disappointing and thousands of would-be gold seekers were left stranded at Rockhampton. Although many returned south
column6: others stayed
column7: adding to the new town's population.

column2: the town boasted a regular newspaper
column3: banks
column4: court house
column5: and school of arts. Direct shipments of imported goods and migrants from the United Kingdom began to be received during the 1860s. In 1862
column6: land in the Kensington Estate
column7: described as just three miles from "the most rapidly rising town and district in the whole of the colonies" was advertised for sale. During the 1860s and '70s
column8: Rockhampton developed as the main port for the developing Central Queensland hinterland
column9: the main export at that time being wool.

column1: === Gold rushes and expansion ===
In the 1880s and '90s
column2: sea ports were established on the coast
column3: adjacent to the mouth of the Fitzroy River. Broadmount was on the northern side and Port Alma on the south. Railways were subsequently constructed to carry goods to the wharves at these locations
column4: with the railway to Broadmount opening on 1 January 1898 and the line to Port Alma opening on 16 October 1911. Maintenance on the Broadmount line ceased in August 1929. The following month
column5: the wharf caught fire and the line was effectively closed in July 1930. The line to Port Alma closed on 15 October 1986.

column1: The significant gold deposit at Mount Morgan to the southwest was discovered in the 1880s
column2: and Rockhampton became the main port through which the wealth of Mount Morgan gold was channelled. Due to the wealth of Mount Morgan
column3: Rockhampton weathered the severe economic depression of the 1890s
column4: and many of the town's substantial brick and stone public buildings date from this period. The historic streetscape of Quay Street still displays a number of substantial historic buildings
column5: built when Rockhampton was envisaged as being capital of a state of North Queensland. Most prominent of these is the sandstone Customs House (1900)
column6: which today houses an information centre. Other important 19th-century buildings include the Post Office (1892)
column7: the Supreme Court House (1888)

column1: In September 1892 the Anglican Church in Rockhampton was the first new building in Rockhampton to be lit by electricity from the new gasworks. It was also the first church in Australia to be lit with electricity.
=== 20th century ===
The City of Rockhampton was proclaimed in 1902. The rail connection south to Brisbane was completed in 1903
column2: but it was not until 1921 that the northern connection to Mackay was finally completed. A railway west from Rockhampton was started in 1867 and by 1892 had reached the terminus at Longreach
column3: 700 kilometres (430 mi) away. This further strengthened Rockhampton's role as the port for the whole of Central Queensland.

column1: A passenger tramway began operating on 16 June 1909
column2: making Rockhampton the only provincial city in Queensland to have a street tramway. Purrey steam trams ran on a number of routes throughout South Rockhampton
column3: totalling 10 kilometres (6.2 mi) of track. The discomfort of passengers riding in steam trams in a tropical climate in part led to their demise in 1939
column4: replaced by a bus network run by the City Council.Strong shaking was felt in Rockhampton when the "Great Queensland Earthquake of 1918" occurred on 7 June 1918. The earthquake was felt from Mackay in the north
column5: to Grafton in New South Wales
column6: and west to Charleville. Estimated to have reached a 6.0 magnitude
column7: the earthquake caused some damage to buildings including chimney stacks crumbling
column8: plaster being dislodged from walls and ceilings
column9: water tanks bursting and trees being uprooted.  Houses and buildings experienced considerable swaying with crockery smashing on the floor and pictures falling off walls. The 1918 earthquake remains as the largest to have ever hit Queensland since European settlement.Restaurant proprietors
column13: ran their business in East Street
column14: Rockhampton. East Street was a bustling metropolis when the brothers opened their traditional Greek café in the 1920s. Previously known as the Australian Café
column15: the brothers renamed it the Busy Bee Café.During the Second World War
column16: a US army base was established outside the city; it hosted up to 70
column17: 000 servicemen en route to action in the Pacific and New Guinea.On 2 March 1949
column18: Rockhampton was severely damaged by a cyclone.The Fitzroy River Barrage was commissioned in 1971. The barrage has a capacity of 81
column19: 300 megalitres and holds back a lake 60 kilometres (37 mi) long. The barrage was funded by the Rockhampton City Council to provide a reliable source of water to the city
column20: and to effectively drought proof Rockhampton. In 2002
column21: a study showed that salinity was increasing in the Fitzroy Basin and
column22: while only small areas of land were severely affected by salinity
column23: urged that steps be taken to manage salinity by good irrigation practices and better management of tree clearing.In 1989
column24: two bombs exploded inside the Shark Nightclub
column25: causing injuries and extensive damage to the building. The following year
column26: the Factory Nightclub was also damaged by a bomb. It is not known who planted the bombs.

column1: === 21st century ===

column2: Rockhampton was the centre of significant national media interest after local teenager Natasha Ryan was found in the North Rockhampton home of her boyfriend
column3: Scott Black
column4: after being missing for five years. Serial killer Leonard Fraser had been charged with her murder
column5: as her disappearance occurred in the period in which Fraser had abducted and murdered other women and girls. An anonymous tip-off during Fraser's trial led to the discovery of Ryan. Despite Ryan's discovery
column6: Fraser's defence did not seek a mistrial and Fraser was convicted of the murders of other women and girls and was given an indefinite life sentence.On 20 February 2015
column7: Rockhampton was severely damaged by Cyclone Marcia damaging hundreds of homes and businesses with wind speeds over 150 km/h recorded in Rockhampton. Major flooding was experienced in the upper reaches of the Fitzroy River after more than 250mm were recorded. The cyclone left about 100
column8: 000 properties across Central Queensland without power.

column1: == Geography ==
The town lies on the Fitzroy River
column2: approximately 45 kilometres (28 mi) from where the river enters the Coral Sea
column3: and some 600 kilometres (370 mi) north of the state capital
column4: Brisbane. Rockhampton has a north and south side with three bridges connecting the two sides
column5: one for trains and two for vehicles and people.

column1: Rockhampton lies just north of the Tropic of Capricorn in Central Queensland. A sculpture originally marking the latitude was later moved into town to be more accessible to tourists. Although the Tropic of Capricorn is represented on maps as a "dotted line" that lies at 23° 26' 22"
column2: there is actually a bio-geographical overlap of Tropical and Temperate zones more than 500 kilometres (310 mi) wide; Rockhampton is roughly at its centre on the East Coast of Australia.

column1: The city is located on the banks of the Fitzroy River
column2: approximately 40 kilometres (25 mi) from the river mouth. The Berserker Range lies on the eastern side of the city
column3: with the Athelstane Range to the west. The coastal area to the east of the city is known as the Capricorn Coast
column4: with the rapidly growing town of Yeppoon its major centre.

column1: === Climate ===
Rockhampton experiences a humid subtropical climate (Köppen climate classification Cfa/Cwa). The city is situated on the Tropic of Capricorn and lies within the southeast trade wind belt
column2: too far south to experience regular north west monsoonal influence
column3: and too far north to gain much influence from cold fronts sweeping in from the Southern Ocean. Typical temperature ranges are 22 to 32 °C (72 to 90 °F) in the summer/wet season and 9 to 23 °C (48 to 73 °F) in the winter/dry season. The city receives 116.3 days of clear skies annually.

column1: Rockhampton lies within the cyclone risk zone and has experienced several large cyclones since European settlement.

The Rockhampton area is also subject to summer thunderstorms. There is a high incidence of winter and early spring fogs. Maximum temperatures in the low to mid 40s have been recorded in October to March.

The Fitzroy River at Rockhampton has a long and well documented history of flooding with flood records dating back to 1859. The highest recorded flood occurred in January 1918 and reached 10.11 m (33.2 ft) on the Rockhampton gauge. The second highest flood in Rockhampton was recorded on 19 February 1954
column2: when the Fitzroy River peaked at a height of 9.4 metres. Rockhampton's third worst flood was recorded on 12 January 1991
column3: when the Fitzroy River peaked at 9.3 metres.More recently
column4: Rockhampton was affected by the 2010–2011 Queensland floods when the Fitzroy River peaked at 9.2 metres on 5 January 2011
column5: although the river had been expected to rise as high as 9.4 metres.The highest recorded official temperature in Rockhampton was 45.3 °C (113.5 °F)
column6: while the lowest was −1.0 °C (30.2 °F).

column1: The highest recorded 24-hour rainfall total was 348 millimetres (13.7 in) on 25 January 2013.
== Heritage listings ==
Rockhampton has a number of heritage-listed sites. For details see the List of heritage listed buildings in Rockhampton.
== Governance ==
Rockhampton is governed by the Rockhampton Regional Council. The Council consists of a mayor and seven councillors. The Mayor is elected by the public
column2: and the Councillors are elected from seven single-member divisions using an optional preferential voting system. Elections are held every four years.

column1: Margaret Strelow is the current mayor
column2: having won the mayoral elections in 2013 and 2016. Strelow had also served as Mayor of the former City of Rockhampton from 2000–2008.

column1: The present Rockhampton Regional Council area was formed as a result of the 2008 amalgamation of four local government areas. These were the original City of Rockhampton which comprised most of the Rockhampton metropolitan area
column2: the Shire of Fitzroy comprising Gracemere and surrounding districts
column3: and the Shire of Mount Morgan around the town of Mount Morgan itself.

column1: The fourth local government area was the Shire of Livingstone which comprised the adjacent coastal towns and hinterland to the east and north of Rockhampton as well as some outlying Rockhampton suburbs. However
column2: Livingstone Shire de-amalgamated from Rockhampton Region in 2014 following a referendum.

column1: Before the 2008 amalgamation
column2: the City of Rockhampton had a population of approximately 74
column4: Fitzroy Shire approximately 11
column6: and Mount Morgan Shire approximately 2
column7: 925 people.

column1: Proposed boundary changes between Rockhampton Regional Council and Livingstone Shire Council are under review by the Local Government Change Commission. The changes relate to three suburbs contiguous with Rockhampton City which are presently part of Livingstone Shire. The proposed changes will affect 1170 properties in the suburbs of Glenlee
column2: Rockyview
column3: and Glendale.

column1: == Economy ==
=== Agriculture ===
The agricultural sector
column2: specifically the cattle trade
column3: is a dominant industry in Central Queensland.  The latter has been visually represented around Rockhampton City with a

column1: set of seven large statues of bulls known as the 'Big Bulls'.

Two large abattoirs are located on the south-eastern outskirts of Rockhampton provides employment for people living in Rockhampton and also for refugees from overseas who are recruited when the companies experience difficulty finding local workers to fill vacancies.One meat processing plant is located at Lakes Creek
column2: operated by Teys Australia (a Cargill joint venture) while the JBS meatworks is located at Nerimbera.The Teys Australia meatworks at Lakes Creek was previously owned by Kerry Packer's Consolidated Meat Group. CMG temporarily closed the facility in 2002. It was reopened in 2004
column3: when Consolidated Meat Group announced they had formed a joint venture with Teys Australia. In 2011
column4: Cargill bought out CMG's share in the company.Due to drought
column5: floods
column6: general economic conditions and disputes with workers
column7: both facilities have experienced a number of closures over the years including the closure of the Lakes Creek meatworks from 2002 until 2004
column8: but they are both currently operating as normal.

column1: The Central Queensland Livestock Exchange at Gracemere is one of the largest livestock sales facilities in the country
column2: lies just to the west of the city.Rockhampton promotes itself as the Beef Capital of Australia but the title has been disputed a number of times by the New South Wales town of Casino.The tri-annual Beef Australia Expo held in the city is a celebration of the local area's cattle industry.

column1: === Military ===

There is a permanent military presence in Rockhampton with members of the Australian Defence Force based at the Western Street Army Barracks located near the Rockhampton Airport. To the north of the city lies the extensive Shoalwater Bay Military Training Area where large scale ground
column2: air and amphibious operations are regularly conducted.

column1: Due to its close proximity to the training area
column2: the city regularly sees military movements between the Western Street Army Barracks and Shoalwater Bay
column3: and hosts service personnel from overseas when joint military exercises are held. When these exercises occur
column4: Rockhampton sees a noticeable increase in activity from military transport
column5: including from defence aircraft that are frequently seen at Rockhampton Airport throughout the exercise periods.The local economy is significantly boosted when visiting overseas troops stay in the city while participating in the army exercises.Military training conducted in the Rockhampton area regularly draws the ire of nomadic peace activists who travel to the city to protest the exercises.In 2011
column6: during Exercise Talisman Sabre
column7: a protester made his way onto the tarmac at Rockhampton Airport and attacked a $36 million Tiger helicopter with a garden mattock. The man was ordered to stand trial charged with wilful damage and threatening an aircraft but died before the matter went to trial.

column1: === Tourism ===
Tourism is increasingly playing a role in the economic development of city and surrounds. The city is a convenient distance north from Brisbane to provide an overnight stop for tourists
column2: who can then branch out to visit local attractions and spend money at local businesses including eateries
column3: entertainment facilities or on recreational activities. The Capricorn Coast is a 30-minute drive from Rockhampton
column4: with the islands of the Keppel group easily accessible from there.

column1: Other attractions that are promoted to the tourist market include the Fitzroy River
column2: the Heritage-listed buildings in the CBD
column3: the Rockhampton Heritage Village
column4: the Dreamtime Cultural Centre
column5: the Archer Park Rail Museum
column6: Mount Archer National Park
column7: Rockhampton Botanic Gardens
column8: and Rockhampton Zoo.A national promotional campaign was launched in 2013 to promote the local area as a premium tourist destination
column9: featuring local singer-songwriter Kate Leahy whose song "We Like" featured as the soundtrack to the television commercials that showed the attractions of Rockhampton and the Capricorn Coast.

column1: === Other industry ===
Other industries in the Rockhampton area include the transport
column2: manufacturing
column3: mining and energy sectors.

column1: Rail group Aurizon (previously known as QR National) has a large workforce in the city
column2: which is the meeting point for the main north coast rail line and the line to the major coalfields to the west. However
column3: the company announced in October 2015 that it was closing its locomotive and maintenance depots in Rockhampton with forty jobs lost from the Rockhampton site. Management of Aurizon's Rockhampton site was criticised by the Australian Manufacturing Workers Union in 2016 who described it as "appalling"
column4: prompting 60 workers to walk off the job citing lack of consultation
column5: lack of adequate training for apprentices
column6: a lack of privacy and unfair demands from management for workers to increase productivity.The coal fired 1445 megawatt Stanwell Power Station lies at Stanwell
column7: 30 kilometers west of the city
column8: where Stanwell Corporation provides jobs for people living in Rockhampton. The power station currently has a workforce of about 150 employees and regularly hires new apprentices from RockhamptonSibelco operates magnesia mine at Kunwarara and processing plant at Parkhurst which employs many locals
column9: although the company announced in 2015 that it would axe 57 jobs from its local operations

column1: == Demographics ==
According to the 2016 census of Population
column2: there were 76
column3: 985 people in Rockhampton.

column1: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people made up 7.2% of the population.
82.8% of people were born in Australia. The next most common countries of birth were New Zealand 1.4%
column2: England 1.3%
column3: Philippines 1.1%
column4: India 0.6% and Vietnam 0.4%.

column1: 86.4% of people spoke only English at home. Other languages spoken at home included Vietnamese 0.5%
column2: Tagalog 0.5%
column3: Portuguese 0.3%
column4: Filipino 0.3% and Mandarin 0.3%

column1: The most common responses for religion were Catholic 26.5%
column2: No Religion 22.6% and Anglican 17.1%.

column1: == Culture ==
Many local concerts
column2: performances
column3: events
column4: festivals are held at the Rockhampton's numerous venues throughout the city each year.

column1: The annual Rockhampton Cultural Festival held each August at the Rockhampton Heritage Village features a variety of market stalls
column2: displays
column3: international foods
column4: music and cultural displays.The Rockhampton Showgrounds plays host to numerous events each year. Most notably
column5: the three-day Rockhampton Show is held in June each year.Like many Australian communities
column6: Rockhampton commemorates Anzac Day on 25 April each year. Rockhampton is believed to be the very first city in Australia to hold an early morning commemoration intentionally scheduled to coincide with when the landing at Gallipoli took place
column7: as the city held a "daybreak" service at 6:30 am on 25 April 1916
column9: Alfred Henry Lambton wrote what is recognised as the first crime novel set in Queensland
column10: From Prison to Power.  The novel takes place at the fictitious cattle station
column12: located 200 miles inland from the important tropical Queensland town of 'Rockington' [Rockhampton].Pilbeam Theatre opened in 1979 and is Rockhampton's largest theatre.

column1: The Rockhampton Art Gallery collection
column2: also owned by the Rockhampton Regional Council
column3: is situated next to the Pilbeam Theatre and consists mainly of works by Australian artists from the 1940s to the 1970s.Opened in 1985
column4: closed in 2011 and then re-opened in 2015 the Rockhampton Music Bowl regularly plays host to events including the annual Carols by Candlelight every December.

column1: The tri-annual Beef Australia Exposition is held every third May at the Rockhampton Showgrounds. In 2009 as part of the Q150 celebrations
column2: the Beef Australia Expo was announced as one of the Q150 Icons of Queensland for its role as an "event and festival".Rockhampton has played quite an important role in the production and exhibition of films in Central Queensland.

column1: Films shot in Rockhampton include The Kid Stakes
column2: Buddies
column3: and Broke.

== Attractions ==
Established in 1869
column2: the Rockhampton Botanic Gardens are located on Spencer Street in South Rockhampton. Excellent specimens of palms
column3: cycads and ferns are found throughout the manicured grounds. Some specimens are over 100 years old.Rockhampton Zoo is located between the Botanic Gardens and Murray Lagoon. Animals and birds include koalas
column4: chimpanzees
column5: saltwater crocodiles
column6: freshwater crocodiles
column7: red kangaroos and the rare cassowary.

column1: A second public garden
column2: the Kershaw Gardens
column3: was officially opened in 1988 on the site of the former Rockhampton rubbish dump. Located on the Bruce Highway in North Rockhampton
column4: these gardens specialise in Australian native plants
column5: especially those of Central Queensland. The most striking feature of the gardens is the imitation waterfall constructed on the northern boundary of the site (adjacent to the highway)
column6: which aims to recreate a scene from the Blackdown Tableland.

column1: The Dreamtime Cultural Centre is Australia's largest Cultural Centre and is set on more than 12 hectares of land
column2: with native plants
column3: trees and waterfalls. The major points of interest at the Dreamtime Cultural Centre include the Torres Strait Islander village
column4: didgeridoo playing
column5: Djarn Djarn dancers
column6: and throwing the returning boomerang. Black flying foxes and occasionally Grey-headed flying foxes can be seen and heard at night and are important native pollinators and seed dispersers of over 100 species of trees.

column1: The Archer Park Steam Tram Museum covers the development and history of rail-based transportation in the major central Queensland town of Rockhampton and is set in the 100-year-old Archer Park rail station on Denison Street on the city's southside. The museum tells the story of Archer Park Station (built in 1899) and the unique Purrey Steam Tram
column2: through photographs
column3: soundscapes and object-based exhibitions.

column1: Rising out of Rockhampton's north-eastern suburbs
column2: Mount Archer National Park provides views of the city
column3: and showcases a range of native Australian flora and fauna. Frazer Park
column4: at the summit of Mount Archer
column5: is approximately 604 metres above sea level.

column1: A short drive north of Rockhampton is the Capricorn Caves.
== Health ==
The Rockhampton Base Hospital is situated in the suburb of The Range
column2: and is located around 4 kilometres (2.5 mi) from Rockhampton CBD
column3: and is the major hospital for the Central Queensland Region. The smaller Hillcrest and Mater private hospitals are located nearby. The Australian Red Cross Blood Service is located at the rear of the Base Hospital on Quarry Street.

column1: Rockhampton is a base for the Royal Flying Doctor Service and the Capricorn Helicopter Rescue Service which operates clinics and provides emergency evacuations in remote communities throughout the region.
== Facilities ==

The Rockhampton Regional Council operates the Rockhampton Regional Library Administration and History Centre in Rockhampton on the corner of William & Alma Streets. Branch libraries are located in Berserker ("Rockhampton North")
column2: Gracemere
column3: Mount Morgan and West Rockhampton ("Anytime" at Rockhampton Airport).

column1: == Education ==
The first school
column2: The Rockhampton National School was opened in 1859. Rockhampton is a major education centre for the region and has numerous state and private primary and high schools.

column1: CQUniversity Australia was founded in Rockhampton in 1967
column2: however the university now has more than 30
column3: 000 students spread across 24 campuses and locations Australia-wide. The university has a focus on engagement
column4: social innovation and engaged research
column5: as well inclusivity and has a history as a leading provider of distance education.

column1: The university was recognised within the top 600 universities in the world by the Times Higher Education World University Rankings
column2: and was named among the top 150 universities
column3: under 50
column4: by the Times Higher Education World University Rankings in 2016.The university currently delivers more than 300 education and training offerings
column5: from short courses and certificates
column6: through to undergraduate
column7: postgraduate and research degrees.

column1: Secondary schools in Rockhampton include Rockhampton State High School
column2: North Rockhampton State High School
column3: Rockhampton Grammar School
column4: Rockhampton Girls Grammar School
column5: The Cathedral College
column6: Rockhampton and Emmaus College
column7: Heights College.

column1: == Media ==
=== Newspapers ===
Rockhampton has had a number of newspapers published in the city since European settlement.
The Morning Bulletin is the only surviving daily newspaper
column2: first published in 1861 as the Rockhampton Bulletin and Central Queensland Advertiser.  The title was changed to the Rockhampton Bulletin in 1871 before finally becoming The Morning Bulletin in 1878.  The Morning Bulletin is a member of the Australian Regional Media network of newspapers
column3: now owned by News Corporation.  The Morning Bulletin has also previously complimented their main daily newspaper with a free home-delivered community newspaper
column4: with previous incarnations including titles such as the Capricorn Local News
column5: Rockhampton and Fitzroy News and The Rocky Mirror.

column2: a new Rockhampton newspaper called The Queensland Telegraph was launched by Queensland Media Holdings. However
column3: after publishing the newspaper for about a year
column4: the newspaper's management announced on 17 July 2013 that the local newspaper office had closed.The Central Queensland Herald was a Rockhampton newspaper which was published from 1930 until 1956.  The Capricornian was a Rockhampton newspaper which was published from 1875 until 1929.  In 1929
column5: The Capricornian merged with The Artesian to become The Central Queensland Herald.  The Artesian was a Rockhampton newspaper which was published from 1919 until 1929.  In 1929
column6: The Artesian merged with The Capricornian to become The Central Queensland Herald.  The Evening News was a Rockhampton newspaper published from 1922 until 1941.  The Daily Northern Argus (originally The Northern Argus) was a Rockhampton newspaper published from 1863 until 1896.  In 1897 the newspaper merged with The Record and was published as The Daily Record until 1922.

column1: Established in 2006
column2: industrial magazine publication Shift Miner is also produced in Rockhampton with its head office located in the Rockhampton CBD.

column1: === Radio ===
Rockhampton is serviced by a number of commercial
column2: community and ABC stations

column1: 4RO is Rockhampton's local AM station
column2: owned by Grant Broadcasters. 4RO broadcasts local breakfast and morning programs from its local studios each weekday with all other programming sourced from elsewhere. The music played on 4RO is of the classic hits genre. 4RO broadcasts a local news service in the morning
column3: although the bulletins are prepared and read by journalists based at Grant's Sunshine Coast hub
column4: especially for 4RO and its sister station
column5: 4CC.

column1: 4CC also owned by Grant Broadcasters
column2: is an AM commercial station servicing Rockhampton on a local AM frequency
column3: although its local breakfast show is presented from a studio in Gladstone. 4CC has a classic hits format and also relies heavily on programming sourced from elsewhere.

column1: Triple M Central Queensland is Rockhampton's local commercial FM station owned by Southern Cross Austereo.  The station was previously branded as Sea FM. Triple M broadcasts local programs from its Rockhampton studios each weekday morning
column2: before taking networked programming sourced from Gold FM on the Gold Coast and other Triple M stations. Triple M in Rockhampton also produces a local news service with a journalist based at the station
column3: compiling and recording local news bulletins for Triple M and sister station Hit Central Queensland.  As part of the Triple M network
column4: the station also broadcasts sports coverage such as Triple M Rocks NRL and Triple M Rocks Test Cricket.

column1: Hit Central Queensland
column2: also owned by Southern Cross Austereo
column3: is a commercial FM station servicing Rockhampton on a local FM frequency
column4: although its local breakfast show is broadcast from a studio in Gladstone. The station was previously branded as Hot FM and is skewed towards the younger listeners with a Top 40/pop music format. Following the local breakfast show
column5: the station takes generic Hit Network programming sourced from Southern Cross Austereo's hub at Sea FM on the Gold Coast or nationally networked programs from metropoliton Hit Network stations such as 2Day FM or Fox FM.

column1: ABC Capricornia
column2: originally known as 4RK
column3: is the local ABC station in Rockhampton
column4: servicing the entire Central Queensland region. It broadcasts a local breakfast show and a local morning show each weekday. Friday's local morning show is also broadcast to other stations on the ABC Local Radio network enabling listeners from outside of the local listening area to call into the popular gardening talk back program. ABC Capricornia also has a local news service
column5: produced by local journalists. The station also airs a local Saturday breakfast show
column6: which is followed by a local Saturday morning sports program. Apart from local programming
column7: ABC Capricornia takes national programs like AM
column13: Saturday Night Country and Australia All Over along with a mid-afternoon program
column15: an evening show and a weekend morning program syndicated from Brisbane.  Other national ABC services that are available in Rockhampton on separate FM frequencies include Triple J
column17: ABC Classic FM and ABC NewsRadio.

column1: 4YOU is the local community station
column2: broadcasting local programs from their Rockhampton studio
column3: presented by a number of volunteers. The station is skewed towards the older demographic and plays a lot of easy listening and country music. All programs are locally produced apart from the regular Sunday evening programs the station takes from the national community radio network.

column1: 4US is the local indigenous community station
column2: broadcasting from a studio at the Dreamtime Cultural Centre in Rockhampton servicing the local Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander population featuring traditional music and focusing on indigenous issues and event within its programming content.

column1: KIX Country is a national narrowcast FM broadcasting service provided by Grant Broadcasters
column2: available in Rockhampton.  Kix solely broadcasts country music-themed programming
column3: which includes programs which originate from studios in Bundaberg complemented by some nationally syndicated programming. While Kix transmits on a narrowcast licence
column4: the station is allowed to broadcast commercials.

column1: Other narrowcast radio services available in Rockhampton include racing station
column2: Radio TAB (formerly 4TAB)
column3: Vision Radio Network and Radio FM 88 (Tourist Information).

column1: === Television ===
Rockhampton is served by three commercial stations and two public broadcasters.
Seven Queensland
Southern Cross Nine
WIN Television
ABC TV
SBS TVEach broadcasts television services in digital formats.
SBS offers digital high-definition simulcasts of their main channel
column2: SBS ONE on SBS HD. There are also ten other main channels available: ABC2
column3: ABC3
column4: ABC News 24
column5: SBS Two
column6: One
column7: Eleven
column10: 9Gem and 9Go!. Austar Limited provides subscription satellite television services.

column1: All three main commercial networks produce local news coverage - Seven Queensland and WIN Television both air 30-minute local news bulletins at 6pm each weeknight
column2: produced from newsrooms in the city but broadcast from studios in Maroochydore and Wollongong respectively. Southern Cross Nine airs a regional Queensland edition of Nine News from Brisbane each weeknight at 6pm
column3: featuring local opt-outs for Rockhampton and Central Queensland.

column1: There is also a small television facility at the ABC studios in Rockhampton with a journalist and camera operator employed locally to produce stories for ABC News and programs such as 7.30 and Landline. The journalist can also be required to do live crosses for ABC News 24.  The ABC had also previously produced a nightly local TV news bulletin for Rockhampton and Central Queensland but it was axed in 1985.
== Infrastructure ==
=== Transport ===

Rockhampton is an important transport hub in the Central Queensland region. Rockhampton provides important transport links between the Central Highlands and Capricorn Coast regions and the areas to the north and south of the state. Rockhampton Airport is essential to the viability of the tourism industry.
The Rockhampton region is well serviced by the national and state highway systems
column2: with the city being located at the main junction of the coastal highway
column3: the Bruce Highway
column4: the central western highway
column5: the Capricorn Highway
column6: and the Rockhampton Hinterland is serviced by the Burnett Highway. Driving time is seven and a half hours from Brisbane to Rockhampton.

column1: Rockhampton is also served by long-distance coaches to Brisbane in the south
column2: and as far as Cairns in the north. Daily services operate into Rockhampton with Greyhound Australia. The Hinterland and Central Highlands are also serviced daily by Rothery's Coaches
column3: Pacific Coaches and Emerald Coaches.

column1: Bus services are operated by Sunbus Rockhampton
column2: which operates under the QConnect public transport system. Two bus interchanges are located in Rockhampton City through which the majority of services operate. Service include most parts of the city
column3: Parkhurst in the north to Allenstown and Depot Hill in the south and to The Range and Lakes Creek in the west

column1: Rockhampton has one major taxi company
column2: Yellow Cabs
column3: who service the City of Rockhampton
column4: Gracemere
column5: and also some services in Yeppoon and Emu Park.

column1: Rockhampton railway station is located on the North Coast railway
column2: and is the terminus of the electrified section of line from Brisbane with through diesel service continuing beyond; services are provided by Queensland Rail. Denison St
column3: Rockhampton is one of the few places where the main line runs down the middle of the street. An Electric Tilt Train services connects it to Brisbane
column4: and the Diesel Tilt Train services the station en route to Cairns.

column1: Rockhampton Airport is operated by Rockhampton Regional Council and is located 6 kilometres (3.7 mi) (3.7 mi) west of Rockhampton City. It is Australia's twelfth busiest domestic airport. The airport handles flights to major Australian cities
column2: tourist destinations
column3: and regional destinations throughout Central Queensland. It is an important base for general aviation serving the Central Highlands and Capricorn Coast communities. The airport is also a base for the Royal Flying Doctor Service and the Rescue Helicopter.

column1: === Water ===
The catchment area of the Fitzroy River is approximately 145
column2: 000 square kilometres (almost the size of England).

column1: It contains six major rivers
column2: and Rockhampton and Central Queensland accordingly enjoy abundant good water. The existing and future dams under construction ensure on-going needs for agriculture
column3: industry and domestic purposes are met.

column1: The Fitzroy River Barrage at Rockhampton separates tidal salt water from upstream fresh water
column2: and provides the supply for Rockhampton's domestic and industrial needs.

column1: === Power ===
Central Queensland's major generating facilities
column2: including the Stanwell
column3: Gladstone and Callide power stations
column4: produce the majority of the State's power. Queensland's newest and most technologically advanced powerhouse at Stanwell
column5: 28 kilometres (17 mi) west of the city
column6: came on line in 1993. The Stanwell facility is a key element in the State's program to expand electricity supply and is a major exporter of power station technology.
